text: in this video you'll see how to set up a
multi-account aws environment that uses
best practices for aws
organizations with this service you can
centrally manage multiple accounts
reduce organizational overhead and adapt
the structure of your organizational
units or ous
to meet your business's needs to get
started let's navigate to aws
organizations using aws organizations
you can programmatically create new aws
accounts and allocate resources
group accounts to organize your
workflows apply policies to accounts or
groups for governance and simplify
billing
aws organizations automatically creates
a route to hold the accounts for your
organization
within the root you can create ou's
which are logical groupings of your aws
accounts and other nested ou's
ous make it possible to organize your
accounts into a hierarchy and apply
management controls more easily
let's create a new ou
as a best practice ous should be based
on function or a common set of controls
rather than mirroring your company's
reporting structure
let's create an ou for security
now that our security ou has been
created let's create some ou's within it
we'll create two new ous within security
one for production workloads and one for
non-production work within the software
development life cycle
as you can see we now have two nested
ou's under security
we can easily add new aws accounts to
our organization or move accounts from
one ou to another
let's add a new account that can be used
to test security services before they
are activated at the production level
we'll enter a name for the account and
the email address of the account's owner
when you add or invite an aws account to
your organization it will be placed into
the root by default
let's move the account we just added to
the security pre-prod ou for testing
the account has been moved successfully
next let's skip ahead to see the full
aws
organization account hierarchy after it
has been constructed using best
practices
the organization has nine top level ous
let's look at each of them
the security ou is dedicated to hosting
security related services
resources and access points and should
be managed by your security team
nested within security the production ou
consists of accounts representing basic
security services and functions
the pre-production ou contains the
security tooling test account
the infrastructure ou is for shared
cloud infrastructure services
such as networking and i t services with
a separate account for each service
like the security ou the infrastructure
ou is composed of a production and a
pre-production ou
the next highest priority ous are
directly related to running your product
or service
aws recommends creating a sandbox ou in
which aws accounts are delegated to
individual technologists with the
required access
sandbox ous are for learning and
innovation and should be detached from
your internal network
to prevent excessive usage fixed
spending limits are also advised
next the workloads ou consists of aws
accounts for the software lifecycle
the workload's ou contains a production
ou and a pre-production ou for staging
software services
it is recommended that workload accounts
are created to isolate software services
rather than mapping them to teams to
make the deployed application more
resilient to organizational change
in addition to the foundational and
business oriented ou's just discussed
aws typically recommends a few more
top-level ous for maintenance and
continued expansion
policy staging is a non-production ou
used to verify the results of applying
policies before committing them on a
production level
the ous nested within policy staging
should represent the real
ous that policies will target
the suspended ou is for organizing aws
accounts that have been closed and are
pending deletion from the organization
the primary purpose of this ou is to
serve as a policy target for such
accounts
individual business users is a limited
access ou for business users who are not
technologists
to access and create business related
applications
the exceptions ou covers identified
business use cases that have been
granted an exception from the auditing
or security conditions defined under the
workloads ou
accounts in the exceptions ou are given
a customized security control policy
the deployments ou is used to isolate
aws accounts whose functionality is
related to continuous delivery and
continuous integration or cicd
a deployments ou should consist of a
production and pre-production ou
with aws accounts for each service
deployed as part of your organization's
cicd process
as a best practice the aws accounts in
the deployments ou should correspond to
the aws accounts and the workloads oh
you
ultimately organizing your accounts into
a functional hierarchy
allows you to innovate faster in aws
while helping you meet your security and
scalability needs
you've just seen how to set up a
multi-account aws environment that uses
best practices for aws organizations
you can learn more about this topic in
the description and links for this video
thanks for watching now it's your turn
to try
